This is blocking TPTP from entering iteration 2 testpass.

If I launch server in Run mode with TPTP profiler VM arguments(-XrunpiAgent) and req'd environment variable(PATH) and It works ok. Only failed in profile mode.

The first error occurs if there are no profilers installed, or the extension point is invalid for some reason. I already have a fix that I'll put in for next week's I-build, but since you actually have a profiler I don't think that's the real issue here.

The second problem is coming from Tomcat and has nothing directly to do with WTP. Can you paste the launch command line from both cases (run with your args vs profile) to show that this isn't caused by an invalid profiler args or a pure Tomcat bug?

I have verified the arguments for the run and profile launch configuration on a Tomcat server and they are identic.

TPTP passes the profiling argument through this extension point 

	<extension point="org.eclipse.jst.server.core.serverProfilers">
		<serverProfiler
	        id="org.eclipse.tptp.platform.profile.server.wst.serverProfiler"
	        name="%_1"
	        vmArgs="-XrunpiAgent">
	    </serverProfiler>
	</extension>


I have also verified that if I launch the Tomcat server from the Run configuration and append the -XrunpiAgent vm argument at the beginning of the vm arguments list, then Tomcat server succesfully starts in profiling mode; I can next attach to the server process and collect profiling information.

I think this proves that the problem is not related with a Tomcat or TPTP bug;
it must be a regression introduced in the code that reads this extension point- org.eclipse.jst.server.core.serverProfilers

Sorry, maybe I should have been more specific - can you paste the command line used to launch in run mode (or profiling with hand modified args) AND when launching in profile mode. You can do this by right clicking on the process in the Debug view and going to properties. This will clearly show the differences between the two command lines and should point to where the problem is.

FWIW, I tried with the extension point you provided and it worked ok (command line was fine, but failed at runtime since I don't have TPTP installed).

got it..

I tried that and the problem is that in the profiling scenario, the -XrunPIAgent option passed through the extension point is written down twice.

If I take out the extra argument and run it from the command line, everything works fine. 

This is the profiling command, notice two -XrunPIAgent options


 "C:\Program Files\Java\jre1.5.0_06\bin\javaw.exe" -Dcatalina.base=D:\TPTP\TPTP_0326\eclipse\workspace\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.wst.server.core\tmp0 -Dcatalina.home=D:\ProgramFiles\apache-tomcat-5.5.15 -Dcatalina.deploy=D:\TPTP\TPTP_0326\eclipse\workspace\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.wst.server.core\tmp0\wtpwebapps -Djava.endorsed.dirs=D:\ProgramFiles\apache-tomcat-5.5.15\common\endorsed -XrunpiAgent -XrunpiAgent -classpath D:\ProgramFiles\apache-tomcat-5.5.15\bin\bootstrap.jar org.apache.catalina.startup.Bootstrap start

Tim, From Valentina's comment, it looks like both VM arguments from extension point and implementation class got passed to the command line. It is not clear from the schema file which one is used when both are supplied. 

1) If I have VM arg put in both plugin.xml and ServerProfilerDelegat, it fails with the following command:
 D:\java_ibm_1.5.0_SR4\bin\javaw.exe -Dcatalina.base=D:\ibm\4400i2tp1\eclipse\runtime-New_configuration\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.wst.server.core\tmp0 -Dcatalina.home=D:\servers\apache-tomcat-5.5.23 -Dcatalina.deploy=D:\ibm\4400i2tp1\eclipse\runtime-New_configuration\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.wst.server.core\tmp0\wtpwebapps -Djava.endorsed.dirs=D:\servers\apache-tomcat-5.5.23\common\endorsed -XrunpiAgent -classpath D:\servers\apache-tomcat-5.5.23\bin\bootstrap.jar;D:\java_ibm_1.5.0_SR4\lib\tools.jar org.apache.catalina.startup.Bootstrap start

2) I took out the VM arg from ServerProfilerDelegate and keep the one in plugin.xml file, profile server fails. here is the command line:
 D:\java_ibm_1.5.0_SR4\bin\javaw.exe -Dcatalina.base=D:\ibm\4400i2tp1\eclipse\runtime-New_configuration\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.wst.server.core\tmp0 -Dcatalina.home=D:\servers\apache-tomcat-5.5.23 -Dcatalina.deploy=D:\ibm\4400i2tp1\eclipse\runtime-New_configuration\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.wst.server.core\tmp0\wtpwebapps -Djava.endorsed.dirs=D:\servers\apache-tomcat-5.5.23\common\endorsed -classpath D:\servers\apache-tomcat-5.5.23\bin\bootstrap.jar;D:\java_ibm_1.5.0_SR4\lib\tools.jar org.apache.catalina.startup.Bootstrap start

3) I tried taking both VM arguments out from the TPTP plug-in and the profile server still fails.
 D:\java_ibm_1.5.0_SR4\bin\javaw.exe -Dcatalina.base=D:\ibm\4400i2tp1\eclipse\runtime-New_configuration\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.wst.server.core\tmp0 -Dcatalina.home=D:\servers\apache-tomcat-5.5.23 -Dcatalina.deploy=D:\ibm\4400i2tp1\eclipse\runtime-New_configuration\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.wst.server.core\tmp0\wtpwebapps -Djava.endorsed.dirs=D:\servers\apache-tomcat-5.5.23\common\endorsed -classpath D:\servers\apache-tomcat-5.5.23\bin\bootstrap.jar;D:\java_ibm_1.5.0_SR4\lib\tools.jar org.apache.catalina.startup.Bootstrap start

looking at the usage of org.eclipse.jst.server.core.internal.JavaServerPlugin.getServerProfilers(), it seems that only the one in ServerProfilerDelegate is used (as in org.eclipse.jst.server.tomcat.core.internal.TomcatLaunchConfigurationDelegate.launch(ILaunchConfiguration, String, ILaunch, IProgressMonitor)

I will attach the TPTP plugin.xml and delegate class for your reference.

Created an attachment (id=62153)
TPTP implementation of ServerProfilerDelegate

and here is the extension in TPTP plug-in (org.eclipse.tptp.platform.profile.server.wst)

	<extension point="org.eclipse.jst.server.core.serverProfilers">
		<serverProfiler
	        id="org.eclipse.tptp.platform.profile.server.wst.serverProfiler"
	        name="%_1"
	        class="org.eclipse.tptp.platform.profile.server.wst.internal.TPTPServerProfilerDelegate"
	        vmArgs="-XrunpiAgent">
	        
	    </serverProfiler>
	</extension>

Sorry, maybe it wasn't clear from the extension schema but you should only specify one of the class or vmArgs attributes - you don't need to provide the same information twice. The class attribute is basically a replacement where you can now specify vmArgs and environment vars, and it is done programmatically instead of in plugin.xml.

So "migration" to the new support should include removing the vmArgs attribute from the extension point, and I can also use this bug to improve the schema doc and provide better fail-over if someone tries to use both. However, that's still not a reason for it to fail in all those cases.

Can you explain what kind of failure you saw in 1) and 2) above? Those both look identical to what I would expect and what it looked like in previous releases... am I missing something in the command line, or is there a different reason it's failing?

1)vm arg in both plugin.xml and ServerProfileDelegate

Asad, this extension is packaged in TPTP releases. You will have to get the TPTP latest release from www.eclipse.org/tptp in order to see the extension in plug-in org.eclipse.tptp.platform.profile.server.wst

Hi Eugene,
Thanks for the last post, I now understand what the problem is. The earlier extension point without the class attribute threw me off.

For the first problem (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException), the fix is already in the weekly WTP I-build.

For the runtime problem, anything you specify as the environment is always appended. I believe you are hitting JDT behaviour, not server tools.

Let me demonstrate with an example. I wrote a Java main() class with the following line:
   System.out.println(System.getProperty("java.library.path"));

When I run this I get the following output:
  D:\jres\j2re1.4.2_04\bin;.;C:\WINDOWS\system32;C:\WINDOWS;
  C:\Program Files\ThinkPad\Utilities;C:\WINDOWS\system32;
  C:\WINDOWS;[... some ommitted ...]D:\tools\bin

If I open the Java Application launch configuration and add the environment variable "path=c:\test" (using append), the output is now:
  D:\jres\j2re1.4.2_04\bin;.;C:\WINDOWS\system32;C:\WINDOWS;c:\test

It looks like JDT is not getting the full path when you try to append to the environment (or appending to the path is somehow messing up the Java library path), which is identical to what you're seeing when you append to Tomcat's environment. Based on this I think you need to do some investigation with a regular Java launch config or talk to the JDT team about this.
FWIW I get the identical behaviour if I try to modify Tomcat's path in the Environment tab, which also points to JDT.
Move to JDT/Debug
This is blocking profile on server (TPTP-WTP integration) to work in upcoming M6 drop.

Appending to an environment appends a *variable* to the existing enrvironment - it does not append the value to the variable. So, appending take the original environment and adds any variables you add, and replaces any variables that already exist (this way you don't have to specify a complete evnrionment - you just modify the variables you care about).

I believe this is working as designed.

The other thing to note is that the VM seems to modify the path - although you just specify "c:\temp" on the Path, the vm is modifying the path at runtime in some way - i.e. it's adding its bin directory.

(In reply to comment #22)
Tim, since the PATH value is replaced instead of append, the server configuration should retrieve the system PATH value, read the extra VM arg from the WTP extension and append to the retrieved value before replacing the PATH value.

WTP server tools isn't in a position to try adding Java server profiling specific path append support when the platform doesn't even support this. I've taken a quick look at the code debug has to determine the current environment for each OS, and this is complex stuff - it doesn't belong nor could we maintain it in WTP.

Try this as the variable value:

${env_var:Path};C:\test

This appends the existing variable.
Note - if the environment is case sensitive, then you must be careful when specifying the variable name.

Hi Tim, I am reopening this bug, I can add the variable in the serverProfiler class, however it has to be substituted in the launcher code.

Notes:

 1. This function is really an extension of enhancement bug 142100 - realizing that the basic support added there is not adequate (or maybe was not specified well enough) for TPTP's requirements.

 2. To be able to do this we need to always get the full environment when the server is run in profile run, but getEnvironment() only returns the environment when the user is trying to override/append it. It looks like Platform debug exposes everything we'd need here via ILaunchManager.

 3. The equivalent code in Platform debug is about 55 lines. Most of it is generic and could be reused, but about 20 lines deal with win32 case-insensitive variables. This kind of code is outside the scope of WTP and we should not be picking it up or maintaining it.

 4. Variable substitution is done via the org.eclipse.core.variables plugin. Since the existing plugins don't use this, it is a new dependency.

 5. Current design would mean that the new code (+ new plugin dependency) needs to change in a minimum of two plugins in WTP and one adopter product. Worst case actually adds two or three external adopter products.

WTP 2.0 M6 isn't officially released until Friday, but like other Eclipse projects we are officially shutdown past API and feature freeze. Given 3, 4, and 5, this is beyond the scope and kind of change that can be included at this point.

The original problem that this bug was opened for was already fixed, but if the new issue is critical then it is time to start discussing other options or defer further enhancements until the next release.

I've received notes off-line about this from Joanna and Harm, indicating the importance of this enhancement for this release of TPTP. I'm waiting for response to ensure that TPTP is willing to back that up by accepting a late change.

My proposal is that we change ServerProfilerDelegate to include a single method that processes a complete JDT VM runner configuration:

  public abstract class ServerProfilerDelegate {
     public abstract void process(VMRunnerConfiguration vmConfig);
  }

This method would be called just before launch when the vmConfig is completely setup. The profiling implementor would just check current settings via the get methods on the vmConfig and change anything they want via setters. When it returns the modified vmConfig will be used to launch the Java app.

Instead of the current practice of implementing individual bits of the config separately (VM args last release, environment this release, etc.), this gives TPTP full access to the entire config in one shot. I'll admit that this shifts the weight of implementation for this specific feature from WTP to TPTP. If TPTP needs to extend or replace the environment, they would copy the code from JDT or write their own implementation. However, there are several benefits from this approach:

 1) Any changes (new dependencies, JDT calls, etc.) are moved to TPTP to correspond with the new function that requires them, instead of being where they don't belong in WTP or teams that extend WTP with products or server adapters.

 2) This is the third request for enhancement from TPTP in as many years, but exposing the entire VM config at once is clean and should cover future requests 4, 5, or 6. It should take WTP out as the bottleneck for new TPTP features.

 3) Likewise, TPTP has full control. They can implement new features immediately and the cost/benefit can be easily evaluated.

 4) Server adapters only need to react to this change once and can benefit for any future changes to TPTP. Going down the other path would only lead to less servers that support TPTP or don't work with current TPTP releases.

This discussion only highlights that this function is just a generic hook to launch Java applications in profiling mode. It really has nothing to do with WTP or servers and was put here originally as a stopgap measure. Once this issue is resolved we should reopen the discussion with the platform.

Tim, Thanks first for your time and effort on investigation a better solution to serve the TPTP request. I did some quick try and test with your proposed new approach and noted that unless there is user input in the launch configuration dialog or the VMRunnerConfiguration will always return null on VMRunnerConfiguration.getEnvironment(). I am not sure if this is a limitation of the DebugPlugin.getDefault().getLaunchManager().getEnvironment(configuration). Even though the new method allows more control on the launch config settings, but it is unsure that it actually serves the variables that TPTP is asking for at the moment. I will set up a meeting with you this week (Apr 9) to discuss this new approach.

This was one of the issues raised in comment 35 and appears to be working as designed in the platform, i.e. if the user hasn't changed the environment themselves then getEnvironment() returns null and this causes the default environment to be used for the launch.

If the environment is null when you get the vmConfig you'd have to do what LaunchManager.getEnvironment() does, calling ILaunchManager.getNativeEnvironmentCasePreserved() to get the current environment and then proceeding with your edits as usual.

Met with Eugene today and finalized design and a last minute requirement. Eugene was been able to make good progress just based on the new method signature here, and things seem to be hanging together.

I've completed my first pass at all the changes in WTP (o.e.jst.server.core, o.e.jst.server.tomcat.core, and o.e.jst.server.generic.core) and checked them into HEAD. I'll start to follow up with impacted external teams and plan to release to WTP I-build this week (if everything goes really smoothly) or next.

Eugene - Please synchronize with CVS to pick up my planned changes and confirm it all looks ok.

Tim, I refreshed the latest jst plug-ins from CVS and refactored my patch with the new signature. I confirm that the new API works with the profile on server function and the JVM_version of the target env can be retrieved with the new signature.

Do you know when will this code be released in an I-build?

Thanks again!
Code released to this week's WTP 2.0 I-build.
